@AndrewNebus @alanlepo @jbordeaux what you said is by far the most common behavior. If recipient is online IM them otherwise email them.
@jbordeaux @AndrewNebus @alanlepo it's not just the response. It's knowing that you saw it. When people text they trust that it gets seen.
@AndrewNebus @alanlepo @jbordeaux which is why SMS works great with no presence indicators. They are unnecessary.
@AndrewNebus @alanlepo @jbordeaux but on mobile with push notifs the concept of presence is fuzzier. You're kind of always present.
@AndrewNebus @alanlepo @jbordeaux Exactly. If recipient is present you have a synchronous IM convo. Otherwise use something else for async.
@alanlepo @jbordeaux this is why IM conversations tends to be mostly 1-1 and newer more mobile services work better for group messaging.
@jbordeaux @alanlepo yes, typically instant messaging is synchronous and requires all parties be present. That's how people use it.
@alanlepo @jbordeaux usually in an IM convo you have a discrete start (Are you there?) and end (Gotta go). That's why I mean by synchronous.
@alanlepo @jbordeaux you can but most don't. If the presence bubble isn't green you'll probably fall back to something async like email.
@alanlepo @jbordeaux IM (Desktop) is synchronous and messaging (mobile) is asynchronous. IM requires everyone be present, messaging doesn't.
@jbordeaux At Yammer we tried to sync email threads to feeds and it never worked because of all the different email clients/formats.
@jbordeaux @alanlepo This is an example of what I mean by a disjoined UX between sender & recipient. This won't work. http://t.co/C3TbxB5SPJ
@alanlepo @jbordeaux in other words MS Send will never have key mobile messaging features like presence, typing indicators, read receipts.
@alanlepo @jbordeaux things like MS Send create a disconnected UX because the sender & receiver have different experiences and expectations
@alanlepo @jbordeaux any app built on top of email will always run into the severe limitations of SMTP, a 30 year old protocol.
